title: I'm writing a fantasy story. What are some clichés I should avoid and what are some possible alternatives to said clichés? - Quora

response.answer_text: These are some cliches I absolutely HATE—but can always expect, to such a degree that I can sometimes peg them the instant they introduce a character in the first few chapters: The big, lovable guy’s going down. They will introduce to you a lovable big guy—a gentle giant, maybe? Or perhaps a large, loud, mountainous man with no manners who just makes you love him anyway—and he’s going to die in the end. It will probably be in a heart-wrenching, heroic way, or just in a sad “shouldn’t have happened” sort of way, but he’ll die none the less.The enemy who was a former friend. Oftentimes in movies, they show these strong, formidable former-friends or brothers who’ve now decided to turn on the protagonist for some reason or another (the reason varies, but often it has little to do with the protagonist himself and more about circumstances out of the protagonists’ hands). The strong friend rarely stays on the protagonist’s side but rather ends up becoming an obstacle he must overcome. And, that former friend is often (albeit, not always) destined to one of the following fates: A) To remain a bad guy who hates the protagonist until defeated, or B) to snap out of their evil ways on their death beds and express regret over their choices. But once they’ve settled into their evil ways, there’s no sign of regret or any lasting feelings or empathy towards their best friend or brother they’re now trying to kill. It’s 100% dedicated hatred. I’m not interested in that.Romance. Every story seems to have a romantic pairing—especially if the hero is a male protagonist. It’s almost like it’s in the story handbook: “must fall in love by the end of the story, and love interest must somehow either A) need rescuing, B) help save the day, or C) Both—” Far too often, romance sort of cheapens the themes to many stories. It complicates things—and often not in a good way. Heck, it’s such a modern compulsion that “The Hobbit” movie created an entirely new character who was never in the book just for the sake of having a couple, which destroyed the emphasis on the brothers’ bond in “The Hobbit,” as well as Tolkien’s point on how bizarre and refreshing it was to have a Dwarf and Elf become friends in “Lord of the Rings.” Additionally, “The Giver” movie made a romantic pairing with a girl who rarely spoke in the book, but for the movie she had to help the protagonist escape and was the main reason he was able to push himself forward.Those who talk about their future before a climax are probably going to die. This one is not always a given, and you have to keep an eye out for other indicators, but I can almost always tell who’s going to die before a big fight when they start their “when this is all over, I want to…” hopes and dreams discussion. It is cliche, but the effect usually is to try to establish more characterization so it hurts the reader/viewer more when they die. Also, it’s not uncommon for people to try and talk about the future when they are trying not to think about dying—but still, it’s a big red flag to many readers.The Under-est Underdog vs. Most Likely to Succeed—This is two in one, but the hero is probably one of the two—either A) Mr. or Ms. Perfect (who needs no help, who is handsome and beautiful, who can do everything because they are just so awesome—even if they don’t know it yet, and even if they are humble about it. Truth is, they probably carry the team, to include any friends who tag along). OR the hero is B) the MOST awkward, most unlikely, biggest loser who finds out they are the last hope or chosen one with ultimate potential. The one who everyone expected to fail who can rub his or her success in their doubters’ faces by the end. There are fewer average Joes in the literary world because they take more work to write. A perfect character or a “loser” character already has most of the development created by going off the expectations already in the reader. However, the average Joe is an individual who has to be introduced to the reader. Unlike the underdog or most likely to succeed, we don’t know the average Joe’s strengths or weaknesses. We can expect Ms. Perfect to be pretty and popular. We can expect Underdog to be socially awkward and possibly bullied. What about Joe? What can he do? How would he fare?Cannon Fodder. It usually seems that writers want to have the reader or viewer feel some sort of loss in battle to make it feel realistic—but it’s too early for any major characters to die without destroying the plot or jeopardizing the mission. So, they create the extras, a no-name. If you see the protagonist(s) fleeing with one or two unknowns (a random guard, a friend of a friend you don’t know, some mundane member of the group who previously had no real appearances until now) you can expect that to be the sacrificial character. They’ll probably stay behind to buy the other characters time or be hit in the crossfire or something. It’s actually humorous when you can peg it before it happens. “Wait, who is this guy? Ah, the cannon fodder.” Sometimes writers try to introduce them a little bit before hand by throwing in a short introductory scene or two hoping to make you like them more (and sometimes it works, but you have a short time to make people like them), but ultimately, they’re just extras for the purpose of being killed off.“To Be Continued...” Books aren’t complete anymore. Apart from me not liking it, with my students, I’ve noticed that this also discourages many who aren’t really into books (but who’d like to at least try to be). For them, it’s intimidating and robs them of the accomplishment of finishing. After all, there’s nothing more frustrating then dedicating the time to a book to find it’s “Book 1” and will probably be in publishing for the next several years. I want to feel excited about a story and victory at having completed it at its end. Yet, “to be continued” stories leave me with a bad taste in my mouth. As such, this is one of the 3 big things that will make me drop a book almost instantly. Don’t get me wrong; I’ve read books in a series or trilogy before and loved them—but now these books are ALL a series or trilogy! And often, I find that I waited forever for book 2 and was seriously disappointed when I finally obtained it and started reading it. Waiting for book 2, 3, and more may cost you readers. Like Eragon—did anyone really even care about that book anymore by the time the last book came out?Know that it’s not always bad to use cliches, but you have to be very careful when using them. If used correctly, they can still be good. If using them cleverly, you can defy expectations and be ironic. But, note—especially when starting out in writing—it’s very dangerous for your story to use cliches.

I like reading and watching stuff in the sci-fi/fantasy category and if I chose things I’d like to see fixed: Power Inflation Typically there’s a set up of good guys versus some sort of bad guys. Then the bad guys are defeated. If you’re writing a one-shot deal, then you’re good but if you’ve got a longer sequence of books then what typically ends up happening is that the next bad guy is even more powerful than the last. It’s done for dramatic reasons. However, it’s silly. Say originally you’re fighting vampires but then the last bad guy is the uber-vampire. Okay good. But then, next time around you think it’s not interesting to fight vampires again and they already defeated an uber-vampire. So, now they have to fight the mega-alpha-vampire and then that leads up to the super-duper-mega-ultra-alpha-and-omega-vampire. Then it just gets stupider from there. The point is to make the journey, or the story, or the situation interesting rather than the enemy. Then you don’t have to resort to power inflation. Spaghettifying Factions Another issue is that some authors like to continuously introduce spice to their story by introducing yet another unknown faction, or person, or character trait. Character traits that don’t exist at the beginning of a novel should be earned. A cowardly character learns to be brave. I dislike novels in which a character is made more interesting by suddenly revealing they actually have witch powers but they were a normal before. By the last chapter everybody and their mom secretly had a long ancient bloodline that gave them powers. That just gets silly. The other macro-version of this is the constant introduction of new factions. Your characters face orcs. Then they fight the orcs for a while. Your war story goes nowhere. Now you introduce dark elves. That goes nowhere. You introduce shadow ogres. Before you know it, even you don’t know what factions you wrote up. An Unnecessary Destiny or Prophecy If you’ve got a good plot lined up, or a good premise (eg. three factions are beset against one another and you follow the Byzantine politics of faction A) then don’t randomly throw in destiny or a prophecy. It tends to be plot cancer that overrides all your other threads for no good reason. Needlessly Attacking Cliches Lastly, don’t needlessly throw away cliches because they are cliches. Doing them well makes for a good plot.  Anyway, without knowing anything about the type of fantasy story you are writing, I can only give you my personal grievances of fantasy/sci-fi in the world.
